In fact each instance of the relay needs an IP on a network that has routing to the DHCP server. This means for every namespace, we consume one IP on this management network. For this reason, the DHCP proposal [1] that Don Kehn made is preferable over this one.

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/dhcp-cpnr-integration

The relay agent would set DHCP option 82 (circuit ID) based on the Neutron L2 segment.

Ack. Actually it looks like we are using the link-selection sub-option for this. Because the relay IP in the tenant network is not routable for the DHCP server, the "giaddr" value is set to the IP in the management network, while the link-selection sub-option is set to the relay address in the tenant network. The server then uses the management IP of the relay agent to communicate with the agent, but the IP in the sub-option to determine the appropriate subnet for the address allocation.

The fact that there is a relay agent *per network*, with a separate IP in the management network is how traffic is isolated between tenants.

In the single-process model, with a single IP in the management network, it become necessary to use the vpn ID or circuit ID to differentiate, because address in the tenant network is not sufficient. That is, you could use the vpn ID or circuit ID to differentiate the tenant and specific tenant network.

Not limited using a single VG. Using this proposal, we can also create multiple backends with multiple VGs using same volume_backend_name on single cinder node. In this case, operation or I/O workload are balanced to these backends.

[LVM_shared1]
volume_group=vg1
volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.xx
volume_backend_name=LVM_shared

[LVM_shared2]
volume_group=vg2
volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.xx
volume_backend_name=LVM_shared

[LVM_shared3]
volume_group=vg3
volume_driver=cinder.volume.drivers.xx
volume_backend_name=LVM_shared

Do you know why it is lost after the first exception? Perhaps we should find this out before we retry an event lots of times.

Well, in my case it's a strange reply from gerrit.

When a new event enters _handleEvent its details are queried in gerrit (using function _getChange). For some reason the change from the event might not be found at the moment:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/zuul/trigger/gerrit.py", line 108, in run
    class Gerrit(object):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/zuul/trigger/gerrit.py", line 98, in _handleEvent
    def run(self):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/zuul/trigger/gerrit.py", line 368, in _getChange
    else:
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/zuul/trigger/gerrit.py", line 400, in updateChange

Exception: Change 1191,1 not found

If zuul would try to fetch that data again it succeeds, a valid data is returned.

But with the exception the event is lost and it won't be requested again, until a new patchset or comment are added.

Right, so I think we should try and determine why this is. I haven't seen any patches miss out being queued in openstack's gerrit. Perhaps it's a network thing?

If it is a network issue, seems like the better place for a TTL might be in getChange.

Agreed with Victor about storing even loop.

The executor may be built in a different thread than the thread used to run the executor. test_executor exactly does that. It's even worse: the thread which will run the executor does not exist yet when the executor is created.

In trollius, all functions implictly retrieve the event loop using trollius.get_event_loop() if the loop parameter is not set (which is the most common case). For example, the trollius.async() function is common and is rarely used with the loop parameter set.

I prefer to store the event loop instead of calling get_event_loop() at each call to _coroutine_wrapper(). It should be more efficient, and it helps also to detect bugs when trollius is in debug mode. For example, it should raise an exception if _coroutine_wrapper() is called in the "wrong" thead (a thread different than the thread running the executor).
Is this the generally agreed pattern for getting an event loop vs. just taking it from the constructor as a constructor parameter?
Ditto here. If some other library/program/application is using trollius along with oslo.messaging doesn't this break that other user?

I focused on the Oslo Messaging repository: the only user of the aioeventlet executor is the test_executor if I understood correctly and this test uses a thread.

You are right that it's better to setup and run the event loop in the application.

I discussed with Mehdi and he agrees. I posted a new patch which doesn't run the event loop anymore. It includes instead a comment explaining how to setup and run the aioeventlet event loop.

Isn't this sort of a bad thing for a library like oslo.messaging to do (to set global state in some other library)?

Maybe it should just abort at this point instead of trying to initialize trollius with an eventloop.

Ok missed this correlation, but still you can avoid copy-paste by adding another parameter to _check_subnet_data in project/networks/workflows.py that will allow to disable this additional check. Example:

# project/networks/workflows.py
    def _check_subnet_data(self, cleaned_data, is_create=True,
                           check_private=True):
        ...
        if cidr:
            ...

                    getattr(settings, "RESTRICT_PRIVATE_NET_CIDR", True)):
                ...
                
# admin/networks/subnets/workflows.py
    def _check_subnet_data(self, cleaned_data, is_create=True,
                           check_private=False):

            cleaned_data, is_create, check_private

One way, yes, but this can also be accomplished with tags.

I agree with mike and yolanda about binding a story type to a branch or git repository. We already support one group that has no git repository (ux), and we are very likely to start supporting others (win the enterprise, etc). By forcing each project to use git, we exclude these groups, which is unacceptable.

This feature also presupposes that storyboard has some way of associating a versioned source repository with a project, story, or task. At the moment we do not yet have any such concept, so until we agree on how, and where, and in what way those things are linked, this entire specification is building on vaporware.
This may also be handled via tags.

My re-collection (and it's been a while) is that interface-attach does not currently work with ports that are associated with a SR-IOV VF, that is you must create the port and attach it at boot - you can't attach it later. I can't however recall WHY this is the case, and this spec doesn't in it's current form do a lot to remind me :)
I am not sure what will cause. Some network or router related to the DHCP agents may let user can not delete the agents.
we are not create the port, we just converting the port to pci request as needed, and allocate pci devices.  -:)

I don't understand why anything needs to change in Nova, actually. When creating a new port in Neutron, the port should be able to be specified as belonging to a SR-IOV VF and not a "normal" vNIC. The port binding information returned from Neutron to Nova should already contain information about the type of port (including PCI device information) and this information should trigger behaviour in libvirt's VIF classes. I don't see why there needs to be any change in Nova's existing attach_interface APIs.
What does "and we will create a normal interface without "physical_network"" mean?
Done

Users of a cloud system should not want or need to know anything about the underlying physical hardware; knowing anything about the underlying hardware goes against the whole idea of virtualization, IMO. Users of cloud systems should only speak or think in terms of the abstract: tiers of network performance. So, the use case here should be more along the lines of:

Alice wants certain virtual machines to have access to faster networking interfaces. She configures her virtual machine instance as normal. After launch, Alice wishes to add a new network interface to her virtual machine that has better performance than the network interface already on her VM. She calls an API to attach a new network interface, passing in some tag that indicates a better tier of performance for the interface.
